flask_messenger package¶

Module contents¶

class flask_messenger.Messenger(app=None, webhook_token={}, access_token='')¶

Bases: object

Messenger api class. Example Usage:

app = Flask(__name__)
messenger = Messenger(app, webhook_token={'/webhook': 'VERIFY_TOKEN'}, 
    access_token='whatever-it-is')

@messenger.on("messages")
def handle_text(msg_obj):
    if msg_obj.text == 'hello':
        messenger.reply_to(msg_obj, text="Hi, how may i help you?")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    app.run()
Parameters

  • app – The flask application instance. If the application instance is unknown when instantiating this class, then call messenger.init_app(app) when the application instance is available.

  • webhook_token – A dictionary of webhook endpoints, verify token pair. The endpoint must be a valid flask endpoint string. i.e It must start with as ‘/’. The verify token is a string of the verify token you set in your facebook developer dashbord.

  • access_token – Optional. This is your api access token which is used when sending messages.

Note

All method parameter types are strings unless stated otherwise.

add_webhook(endpoint, token)¶

Add or override existing webhook anytime.

Parameters

  • endpoint – A valid endpoint string.

  • token – The verify token for the endpoint.

events_dispatcher(endpoint, request)¶

Method to get the event type of a webhook event and call the event handler with the appropriate event object.

Parameters

  • endpoint – The endpoint for which the event was sent.

  • request – The flask request object for that event.

init_app(app)¶

Initialize this extension.

on(event, webhook='all')¶

Decorator to register event handler. Usage:

@on(event, webhook)
def handler(event_obj):
    pass
Parameters

  • event – The event to set an handler for. It must be one of messages, messaging_postback, message_deliveries, message_reads or message_reactions.

  • webhook – The webhook endpoint to register the event handler for. webhook can be a single webhook endpoint, list of webhooks endpoint or the string ‘all’ to set the handler for all webhooks endpoint.

reply_to(msg_obj, **kwargs)¶

Reply to a message.

Parameters

  • msg_obj – The message event object whose sender is to be sent a reply.

  • access_token – The page’s access token. Optional if access_token was set when instantiating flask_messenger.Messenger class.

  • text – The text to be sent as message. This is must not be set if attachment or sender_action is set.

  • attachment – An attachment object to be sent. Attachment objects include all the classes defined in flask_messenger.templates or flask_messenger.message.Attachment. Must not be set when sender_action or text is set.

  • quick_replies – Takes a list of flask_messenger.message.QuickReply objects to be sent with the message.

  • sender_action – It can be any of “typing_on”, “typing_off” or “mark_seen”. Must not be set when attachment or text is set.

  • type – The type of the message to be sent. Valid options are ‘RESPONSE’, ‘UPDATE’and ‘MESSAGE_TAG’.

  • notification_type – Valid values are ‘REGULAR’, ‘SILENT_PUSH’, ‘NO_PUSH’.

Returns

A dictionary of the response.

send_message(recipient, access_token=None, text='', attachment=None, quick_replies=[], sender_action='', type='RESPONSE', notification_type='')¶

Send a message using facebook’s send api.

Parameters

  • recipient – The recipient object which is a dictionary of one entry that can have any of the following keys: id, user_ref, post_id, comment_id and the appropriate value.

  • access_token – The page’s access token. Optional if access_token was set when instantiating flask_messenger.Messenger class.

  • text – The text to be sent as message. This is must not be set if attachment or sender_action is set.

  • attachment – An attachment object to be sent. Attachment objects include all the classes defined in flask_messenger.templates or flask_messenger.message.Attachment. Must not be set when sender_action or text is set.

  • quick_replies – Takes a list of flask_messenger.message.QuickReply objects to be sent with the message.

  • sender_action – It can be any of “typing_on”, “typing_off” or “mark_seen”. Must not be set when attachment or text is set.

  • type – The type of the message to be sent. Valid options are ‘RESPONSE’, ‘UPDATE’and ‘MESSAGE_TAG’.

  • notification_type – Valid values are ‘REGULAR’, ‘SILENT_PUSH’, ‘NO_PUSH’.

Returns

A dictionary of the response.

class flask_messenger.ParseEvents(request_dict)¶

Bases: object

Class to parse event data and determine the appropriate event type.

Parameters

request_dict – A dictionary of the data sent by messenger.

parse()¶

Parse the data.

Returns

This method returns a 3-tuple with the first element being the event type, the second element being the raw entry and the last is the appropriate event object.

flask_messenger.message module¶

class flask_messenger.message.Attachment(attachment_dict={})¶

Bases: object

Attachment class.

Parameters

attachment_dict – This is optional and is only used by the flask_messenger.events.RecievedMessage to get the attachment object for a recieved message. The value is a dictionary of the attachment field in the recieved message data.

property coordinates¶

Co-ordinates (lat, long) if the attachment is as a result of a user clicking a location quick reply.

download_attachment()¶
get_dict()¶
Returns

A dictionary of the attachment data.

property is_location_data¶

True if the attachment is as a result of a user clicking a location quick reply.

property is_reusable¶
supportedtypes = ['image', 'video', 'audio', 'file']¶
property type¶
property url¶

URL of the attachment.

class flask_messenger.message.Message(type, recipient, text='', sender_action='', notification_type='')¶

Bases: object

Message class to encapsulate a message.

Parameters

  • type – Type of message. Valid values are ‘RESPONSE’, ‘UPDATE’ and ‘MESSAGE_TAG’.

  • recipient – The recipient object which is a dictionary of one entry that can have any of the following keys: id, user_ref, post_id, comment_id and the appropriate value.

  • text – Text to be sent. Must not be set when either sender_action or notification_type are set.

  • sender_action – Sender action. Valid values are ‘typing_on’, ‘typing_off’ and ‘mark_seen’. Cannot be set with text and notification_type.

  • notification_type – The notification_type. Valid values are ‘REGULAR’, ‘SILENT_PUSH’ and ‘NO_PUSH’. Cannot be set with text and sender_action

add_quick_reply(quick_reply_obj)¶

Add a quick reply to the message. May be called multiple times to add multiple quick replies.

Parameters

quick_replies – A flask_messenger.QuickReply object.

get_dict()¶
Returns

A dictionary of the message data.

set_attachment(attachment_obj)¶

Add an attachment to the message.

Parameters

attachment_obj – An attachment object to be sent. Attachment objects include all the classes defined in flask_messenger.templates or flask_messenger.Attachment. Must not be set when sender_action or text is set.

class flask_messenger.message.QuickReply(type, title='', image_url='', payload='')¶

Bases: object

Quick Reply class.

Parameters

  • type – The type of the quick reply. Valid values are ‘text’, ‘location’, ‘user_email’ and ‘user_phone_number’.

  • title – Title of the quick reply. It must be set when type is ‘text’.

  • image_url – An image to be sent alongside a text quick reply.

Payload

payload for text quick reply.

get_dict()¶
Returns

A dictionary of the quick reply data.

flask_messenger.message.download_file(url, dir_='.')¶

Download a file from a given url into dir.

Parameters

  • url – url to download the file from.

  • dir – optional.The directory to download the file into. Defaults to the current directory.

flask_messenger.message.send_message(recipient, access_token, text='', attachment=None, quick_replies=[], sender_action='', type='RESPONSE', notification_type='')¶

Send a message using facebook’s send api.

Parameters

  • recipient – The recipient object which is a dictionary of one entry that can have any of the following keys: id, user_ref, post_id, comment_id and the appropriate value.

  • access_token – The page’s access token. Optional if access_token was set when instantiating flask_messenger.Messenger class.

  • text – The text to be sent as message. This is must not be set if attachment or sender_action is set.

  • attachment – An attachment object to be sent. Attachment objects include all the classes defined in flask_messenger.templates or flask_messenger.message.Attachment. Must not be set when sender_action or text is set.

  • quick_replies – Takes a list of flask_messenger.message.QuickReply objects to be sent with the message.

  • sender_action – It can be any of “typing_on”, “typing_off” or “mark_seen”. Must not be set when attachment or text is set.

  • type – The type of the message to be sent. Valid options are ‘RESPONSE’, ‘UPDATE’and ‘MESSAGE_TAG’.

  • notification_type – Valid values are ‘REGULAR’, ‘SILENT_PUSH’, ‘NO_PUSH’.

Returns

A dictionary of the response.

class flask_messenger.templates.GenericTemplate(title, image_url='', subtitle='')¶

Bases: object

Class to represent a generic template.

Note

All method parameter types are strings unless stated otherwise.

Parameters

  • title – The title of the template.

  • image_url – Optional. URL of image to be included in the template.

  • subtitle – Optional. Subtitle

add_buttons(button_list)¶

Add buttons.

Parameters

button_list – A list of button objects from flask_messenger.buttons.

get_dict()¶
Returns

A dictionary of the template data.

set_default_action(url)¶

Set a default action for the template. The default action is a url button whose url is opened when the button is clicked if no other button is present.

Parameters

url – URL for the default action button.

class flask_messenger.templates.MediaTemplate(media_type='image', attachment_id='', url='')¶

Bases: object

Media template class.

Parameters

  • media_type – Optional. Type of media to be sent in template. valid values are ‘image’ or ‘video’. Defaults to ‘image’.

  • attachment_id – The id of a previously saved attachment. Cannot be set when url is set.

  • url – The url of the media to be sent with the template. Cannot be set when url is set.

add_button(button)¶

Add a button to the template.

Parameters

button – A button object from flask_messenger.buttons.

Returns

A dictionary of the template data.

class flask_messenger.templates.RecieptTemplate(recipient_name, order_number, payment_method, timestamp=None, currency='USD', merchant_name=None, order_url='')¶

Bases: object

Reciept Template class.

Parameters

  • recipient_name – The name of the recipient.

  • order_number – Order number.

  • payment_method – The method of payment.

  • timestamp – Optional. timestamp for when payment was made.

  • currency – Optional. Currency code. Defaults to ‘USD’.

  • merchant_name – Optional. Merchant’s name.

  • order_url – Optional. Order URL.

  • street_2 – Optional. second street name.
